content:
You're doing great with your water changes and monitoring! Bi-weekly water changes are a good starting point, but it's excellent that you're adjusting your strategy based on your tank's needs.

A slight increase in nitrate levels is not uncommon, and it's great that you're on top of it. To combat the rising nitrate levels, you can consider the following:

1. **Increase water change frequency:** Try increasing the frequency of your water changes to weekly or even every 4-5 days. This will help to remove more nitrates and other waste products from the tank.
2. **Increase water change volume:** Instead of replacing 25% of the tank water, consider increasing the volume to 30-40%. This will help to dilute the nitrates and other waste products more effectively.
3. **Optimize your filter media:** Make sure your filter media is functioning properly and not clogged. Consider replacing the media according to the manufacturer's instructions or adding additional media to increase the tank's biological capacity.
4. **Monitor your fish load:** Ensure that your tank is not overcrowded, as this can contribute to higher nitrate levels. Consider rehoming some fish or upgrading to a larger tank if necessary.
5. **Add nitrate-reducing plants:** Certain plants, like Java moss or Anacharis, are known to help reduce nitrate levels in the tank. Consider adding some of these plants to your tank to help combat the issue.

Remember, it's always better to be proactive about water changes and maintenance to prevent water quality issues. Keep up the good work, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need further guidance!
